title: What satellite does Dish Network use? - Quora

response.answer_text: Which “dish” are you referring to? I guess by dish you’re referring to that disc like curved plate. I also guess the ‘dish’ you are talking about here is most probable for your home TV viewing. Where (country) do you live? Which (digital TV) company is your dish locked to? Satellite service provision is a business - a local company may strike a deal worth billions with a satellite communication provider (e.g. in America or in those developed countries) to supply them the satellite signal. The satellite company - Iridium, has the most number of satellites orbiting the earth Note that different satellites in space do/serve different purposes. e.g. some are dedicated to studying weather, two way communication, digital TV, some are for spy purposes, etc. With modern digital TV service providers, the decoder should be capable of showing which satellite(s) the service is pinged to. Mine here used to show it during manual channel programming The question asked about one specific satellite TV service provider, “Dish Network.” Dish Network is satellite TV service provider like and competitor to DirecTV. Dish Network will have a fleet of satellites it owns and/or transponder usage on someone else’s satellite.

Doesn't use one satellite it uses many, some of those are independently owned but most of them are EchoStar satellites (EchoStar is a subsidiary of Dish). Many satellites can share the same 'orbital slot' which is just a position above the equator. EchoStar uses 110deg West and 119deg West mostly and some other slots for additional content. http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dish_Network
